mods.abstract: Uniformed Tennessee State Guard member with rifle in hand with a backdrop of a manufacturing plant and railroad. There is listed the criteria for enlistment and the individuals to contact, along with businesses and individuals who paid for the advertisement.

Promotions like this appeared in newspapers across the state beginning in the summer of 1943. Their placement heralded an entlistment drive; the Tennessee State Guard forces continued to lose their younger trained members to the Regular Army. A frequently mentioned membership goal was 10,000; the Guard averaged 7,800 during the major periods of military hostility, but experienced a constant drain. The promotions were also used as an opportunity to address common criticisms.
